Award.AwardTitle: Ion Heating in the Magnetotail: Understanding Geomagnetic Storms
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will use global images of energetic neutral atom (ENA) data from the NASA IMAGE and TWINS missions to determine the ion density and temperature as a function of position in Earth's magnetotail. The project will examine how the heating varies between magnetic storms that are driven by coronal mass ejections (CMEs) and those driven by high speed solar wind streams. These observational results will then be used to establish temporally varying boundary conditions for a model of Earth's ring current (the Comprehensive Ring Current Model - CRCM). This will allow the investigation of how the effects of ion heating affect the dynamics of the inner magnetosphere.

Ion heating occurs in the magnetosphere primarily as a result of solar wind forcing and the heating is particularly strong during geomagnetic storms. Thus, understanding the dynamics of the magnetosphere requires the ability to accurately measure the ion temperature and understand how it is affected by varying processes in the solar wind. The dynamics of the terrestrial magnetosphere during geomagnetic storms are important to understand as we become increasingly reliant on satellite-based technologies for tasks from personal communication to national defense. Reliable measurements combined with models that can accurately represent the near-Earth space environment are an essential element to improving our ability to mitigate the adverse effects of space weather. The project includes educational impacts because a postdoctoral researcher and a graduate student will participate in the work. The project also has impacts on under-represented groups. The Principal Investigator is an early-career woman scientists who is involved with public outreach activities coordinated by the West Virginia chapter of the Association for Women in Science

POR.DRECONTENT:
During geomagnetic storms, ions in the magnetosphere are heated through a variety of processes. In particular, heating occurs in the magnetotail through magnetic reconnection, particle drifts, and other phenomena. These heated ions are injected to the inner magnetosphere, populating the ring current that is the primary indicator of storm intensity. Using a novel technique to calculate ion temperatures from energetic neutral atom data, ion temperature maps have been created as a function of time throughout the evolution of many geomagnetic storms.

We have studied the average ion temperature evolution during geomagnetic storms as a function of what type of Sun-originating feature drives the storms. For coronal mass ejection (CME)-driven storms, the magnetosphere is heating at the onset of the storm, primarily by compression of the magnetosphere. In contrast, storms driven by high speed solar wind streams do not experience significant heating until after the peak of the storm, during the recovery phase. Unexpectedly we observed that, for the most intense CME-driven storms, the initial heating is the most significant, but is followed by cooling until the peak of the storm.

Modeling geomagnetic storms is critical to improving our ability to understand and forecast these events. Models of the inner magnetosphere require boundary conditions that define particle characteristics of the magnetotail. These boundary conditions are often provided by statistical models that miss many spatial and temporal variations. We conducted comparative simulations using boundary conditions derived from statistical models and our storm-specific calculated temperatures. These temperatures coupled with the strength of the convection from tail to inner magnetosphere were shown to have a significant impact on the dynamics of the inner magnetosphere. Thus, having accurate ion temperature measurements that cover the full model boundary in the magnetotail are essential to accurate simulations of specific events. A database of calculated ion temperature maps during the evolution of geomagnetic storms has been made publicly available for such studies.

The broader impacts of this award include the participation of 2 undergraduate students, 3 graduate students, and one postoctoral scholar. The postdoc, one graduate student, and one undergraduate student were female. Two of the graduate students have received their PhD and are currently in postdoctoral positions. The postdoc has recently accepted a tenure-track faculty position. This award supported the career of the female PI, enabling her to also mentor these female students toward successful careers in STEM fields. The PI was able to continue her work to support all women in STEM through her involvement with the Association for Women in Science. She also conducted Education and Public Outreach activities, including the development of a program on the Sun and Space Weather, that includes educator training and hands-on workshops for students.
